                                                    Politico
Mike Allen's must-read briefing on what's driving the day in Washington 
09/25/15 07:00 AM EDT
By Mike Allen (@mikeallen; mallen@politico.com) and Daniel Lippman (@dlippman; dlippman@politico.com)
Happy Friday! @Schwarzenegger: “Congrats @cmarinucci on the big job at @politico [as California Playbook writer, launching in a few weeks]. One of the best reporters in California – can’t wait to see you on an even bigger stage.”
Story Continued Below
HIGH T: We’ll see lots of Jeb Bush in the next week, as he tries to seize this moment of Trump weakness. Chris Wallace travels to Miami today to tape Bush “Fox News Sunday” interview at his Miami field office – Jeb’s first Sunday-show interview since May. Bush rolls out an energy plan on Tuesday in Pittsburgh. Then New Hampshire, New York City and South Carolina. Yesterday, he was in Virginia and Kentucky raising money for ’15 elections, then went to South Carolina.
--JEB to JOHN HARWOOD: “I don’t think people are inherently racist in this country. In fact, I think that we have a pretty noble tradition of the opposite. But people are deeply disaffected right now. So rather than prey on their angst and fears, I’m taking a risk of trying to appeal to their hopes and dreams.” http://cnb.cx/1jh5aFO
RUBIO GAME CHANGE -- “The strategy behind Rubio’s Trump feud: The decision to go after Trump is a departure from Rubio’s low-key campaigning style, but the benefits could be huge,” by Marc Caputo, with C.J. Jackson: “Sweaty. Lightweight. ... ‘no money, zero.’ Donald Trump has spent the past two days bashing Marco ... [Yesterday,] Rubio barked back at Trump, calling him ‘a very touchy and insecure guy. ... He takes shots at everybody that gets anywhere close to him, in terms of a poll, or anytime he hits a rough spot that’s what he does.’ ...
“For Rubio, it's a gamble. It ends a long-term strategy of trying to ignore ... Trump. ... Rubio is a skill puncher. Trump’s a brawler. Polling in the middle of the pack, Rubio has been running a low-key campaign that ... has kept him largely out of the spotlight of ... mainstream media. ... ‘I’ve made a decision here with Donald Trump, ... if I comment on everything he says, my whole campaign will be consumed by it. That’s all I’ll do all day,’ Rubio said in August on NBC’s ‘Meet the Press.’ ...
“[S]ince then, Rubio has taken an increasing number of veiled shots at Trump because it plays to ... one of [Rubio’s] strengths: foreign policy. ... Rubio’s criticisms aren’t part of a plan to make the contest a two-way race with Trump — a Bush tactic. ... Rubio’s campaign strategy revolves around waiting for the right opportunity to make news. ... Fiorina ... showed others that the counter-counter-punch can be pretty sweet, as shown by her surge.” http://politi.co/1YEuZ2Y
GRANDPA TRUMP: Daughter Ivanka announced in a 19-second Facebook video that she and Jared Kushner are expecting a third child. http://on.fb.me/1FxE3QN
EMAIL OF THE DAY: TED CRUZ rented out the Daily Caller email list and yesterday tried to goose his email open-rate by using “dropping out” as subject line: “Friend, I’m sure you’ve heard...the crowded field of presidential candidates is beginning to thin out, and what you may not know -- money was a big factor. That's why I’m emailing you today.” See the email. http://bit.ly/1MtuIJj
** A message from the American Bankers Association: If we mandated cellphone technology, we’d still have brick style phones. If Congress mandates a static payments technology, security safeguards will be out of date tomorrow. Let’s Innovate. Not Mandate. Learn more at letsinnovatenotmandate.com **
PAPAL PLAYBOOK – “Pope to Congress: ‘Do unto others ... ,’” by Nahal Toosi: “In white robes that glowed against the backdrop, and flanked by two former altar boys — House Speaker John Boehner and Vice President Joe Biden — the Roman Catholic leader urged lawmakers to cooperate and remember their responsibilities to their fellow citizens, adding: ‘Legislative activity is always based on care for the people.’
“The speech — the first by a pope to a joint meeting of Congress — combined words of faith with unmistakable political and policy appeals and it offered something to like for each of America’s two main political parties. But overall, with their strong emphasis on the environment and welcoming immigrants, calls to end the death penalty and the arms trade, and relatively brief and opaque references to stopping gay marriage and abortion, Francis’ words ... cheered Democrats more than Republicans.” http://politi.co/1MtDfMw Transcript http://ti.me/1LBINWI
--N.Y. POST cover: “HEAVENLY! Francis takes NYC by storm” http://bit.ly/1uTkiZw
--“Inside the House Speaker’s Office with Pope Francis,” by People’s Sandra Sobieraj Westfall: “Boehner enjoyed a private audience, ... where he won papal approval for the hue of his necktie. ‘Green is the color of hope,’ Francis said quietly, and with a twinkly smile, to the congressional leader as the two men sat down in Boehner's office for private talks ahead of the Pope’s historic speech ... A congressional aide described the months of planning for Francis as ‘hundreds of meetings, more than we’ve ever had for any other event.’” http://bit.ly/1OxpAag
TWEETS DU JOUR: @BresPolitico: “Last time we’ll ever see a Fiat parked in front of the Capitol like that. EVER” ... @EvanMcSan: “Biden, caught on open mic with pope on speaker’s balcony. ‘They love you. And we love you’” ... @jpodhoretz: “Liberals liked the global warming stuff and the death penalty stuff. Conservatives liked the family and abortion stuff. I liked the yarmulke” ... @joshuadubois: “Pope, in Fiat, rolling past Ben’s Chili Bowl. If you live in DC, you know how amazing this photo is.” http://bit.ly/1MM9j10
--HOW HIS HOLINESS IS PLAYING: NYT 2-col. lead, “POPE, IN CONGRESS, PLEADS FOR UNITY ON WORLD’S WOES: Asks Lawmakers to Harness Power to Solve Issues on Left and Right” ... USA Today banner, “‘We, the people of this continent, are not fearful of foreigners’” ... WSJ A1, below fold, “Pope Issues Challenge to Congress” ... WashPost, middle of page, “Calls of inspiration, obligation” ... L.A. Times, cols. 1-5, “Francis calls on Congress to seek ‘common good.’”
--NYT Quotation of the Day: POPE FRANCIS, speaking through an interpreter to a huge crowd that had gathered on the West Lawn of the Capitol to watch his address to Congress: “I ask you all, please, to pray for me, and if there are among you any who do not believe or cannot pray, I ask you please to send good wishes my way.”
--“Scalpers turn [Philly] papal tickets for profit, drawing church's ire,” by AP’s Michael Sisak: “The rosary beads cost $175. Sounds a bit pricey, except the Craigslist ad says they come with tickets to see Pope Francis. Same with the $10 train passes marked up to $85 in another listing.” http://bit.ly/1KFPCSQ
DRIVING NEXT WEEK: Obama meeting Putin in N.Y. – AFP’s Andrew Beatty: “The Kremlin and White House said the two leaders will have their first formal meeting in two years on the margins of the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, although they gave differing views as to whether the talks will center around Syria or Ukraine. And the announcement was accompanied by a series of disparaging remarks from the White House.” http://yhoo.it/1FkWQ1U
--CHARLIE ROSE interview of PUTIN in Russia, airing Sunday on 48th season premiere of “60 Minutes”: “Putin says he does not fit the label of ‘czar’ that Americans often apply to him.” Charlie: “What do you admire most about America?” Putin: “I like the creativity.” Video excerpt http://cbsn.ws/1LB1JVE
DRIP, DRIP -- “Hillary approved special status for Huma Abedin,” by Rachael Bade: “Clinton green-lighted paperwork that changed her top aide Huma Abedin’s job status to ‘special government employee’ — a classification that allowed Abedin to work for [Teneo] and the Clinton Foundation at the same time she was advising Clinton at State ... documents obtained by Judicial Watch.” http://politi.co/1KTpcAG
CLINTON CAMPAIGN “Friends & Allies Talking Points” sent yesterday – “Guidance on Bloomberg Report that FBI Has Restored Clinton’s Personal Emails: Assuming the Bloomberg report is true, the reason the FBI may be able to recreate these emails is exactly because ... the rumors that steps were taken to ‘wipe’ the server's contents were never true. Even if FBI can indeed recreate her personal emails as Bloomberg reports, they are unlikely to be released publicly as they are not work-related. ... Hillary Clinton turned over her work-related emails. ...
“GUIDANCE ON WASHINGTON POST STORY ON HOW STATE DEPT REQUESTED CLINTON'S EMAILS: Nothing in this story contradicts what Hillary Clinton has said. ... ”
CHASER – “Hillary’s FBI nightmare: If the feds have Clinton’s personal emails, too, some of them are bound to come out — exactly as she feared,” by Josh Gerstein and Rachael Bade http://politi.co/1KTKgXH
COMING ATTRACTIONS: “Savannah Guthrie will moderate a town hall [on ‘Today,’ Mon., Oct. 5] ... live from New Hampshire ... Guthrie will also sit down with Clinton for a live one-on-one interview.”
--“Biden to Deliver Keynote Address at the 19th Annual [Human Rights Campaign] National Dinner [Oct. 3 in D.C.]: Ellen Page to receive Vanguard Award; Allison Janney to present; Jason Collins and Blossom Brown to speak; ... Carly Rae Jepsen, ... -- joined by hip-hop artist Futuristic -- will perform at sold-out event.” See the release. http://politi.co/1Oy1LPO
HAPPENING TODAY -- “Rubio proposes employer tax credit for paid family leave,” by AP’s Sergio Bustos in Miami: “The Florida senator ... will introduce his plan [this] morning when he speaks before the Values Voter Summit in Washington. ... Rubio would give businesses a 25 percent tax credit for providing at least four weeks of paid family leave. It would be limited to 12 weeks of leave and $4,000 per employee.” http://yhoo.it/1R4PUHm The proposal http://bit.ly/1WmmLu4
SUNDAY SO FAR:
--“Fox News Sunday”: Jeb Bush ... Government shutdown: Rep. Tom Cole (R-Okla.), Appropriations Committee and Rep. Mick Mulvaney (R-S.C.), Financial Services Committee ... Panel: Brit Hume, Anne Gearan, George Will, Juan Williams
--“Face the Nation”: Speaker Boehner, taping this afternoon in the Capitol ... Bernie Sanders ... Panel: Kim Strassel, WP’s Ed O’Keefe, Ron Fournier, Susan Page
--“Meet the Press”: Hillary Clinton ... Carly Fiorina ... Roundtable: David Brooks, Andrea Mitchell, Eugene Robinson, Kristin Soltis Anderson
--ABC “This Week”: Roundtable: Matthew Dowd, Jennifer Granholm, Bill Kristol, TIME’s Rana Foroohar
--CNN’s “State of the Union”: Tapper anchors from 9 to 10 a.m., then from 11 to 1. Nancy Pelosi ... Martin O’Malley ... Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.) ... Philly Mayor Michael Nutter ... Paul Begala, Ana Navarro, Van Jones ... Father Edward Beck, John Allen, Delia Gallagher, Father James Martin
TALE OF THE TAPE -- WashPost Style lead, “Forget polls: Is Hillary rising on height chart?” by Jay Mathews (“Is Hillary Clinton getting taller? Or is the Internet getting dumber?”): “I am the only journalist peculiar enough to have chronicled since 1988 ... the effect of height on electoral success. ... This is my eighth article on the subject. ... When [Clinton] ran for president in 2008, she was only 5-foot-5. I got this official height report from the Clinton campaign [Now, many news organizations – and Google -- say she’s 5-foot-7.] ...
“Donald Trump and Jeb Bush both say they are 6-3, but Trump ... may be exaggerating. At the CNN debate, Bush looked taller. Several candidates said they were 5-foot-11: Ben Carson, Mike Huckabee and Chris Christie. ... Marco Rubio is 5-10; Carly Fiorina, 5-6 ... and Rand Paul, 5-8. ... Nearly all, though, look much taller than Clinton, and here is where I am obliged to say that no matter what the Google algorithms say, she may not actually have grown to 5-7.
“Such elevation at her age is, my research tells me, quite unusual. Some people who have had the privilege of standing near her recently tell me she seems closer to the 5-foot-5 I reported eight years ago. I e-mailed Clinton campaign spokesman Nick Merrill to check the 5-foot-7 reports. ... I haven’t heard from her campaign yet.” http://wapo.st/1PArgNU
SCOOP -- “Cruz super PAC preps Christian radio onslaught,” by Shane Goldmacher: “Cruz’s super PAC is making its first major ad buy, ... launching a $1 million national campaign on Christian and conservative talk radio to run through the end of the year ... The initial 60-second ad will begin running on Monday ... the first from the constellation of four pro-Cruz super PACs that raised a stunning nearly $38 million ... paid for by the Keep the Promise I super PAC, ... funded chiefly by $11 million from hedge-fund magnate Robert Mercer.” http://politi.co/1FxP7gS
PIC DU JOUR -- @realBobWoodward: “Press badges through the years: #ThrowbackThursday” http://bit.ly/1YEuV39
LINGO -- “Office Craze Called ‘Hot Desking,” by Slate’s Alison Griswold: “Assigning desks ad hoc based on who’s there at any given time, because you don’t have space for everyone ... The practical goal of hot desking is to distribute too few desks among too many people, in a sort of never-ending office musical chairs. The management-jargony goals, on the other hand, are to ‘encourage new relationships,’ ‘chance interactions.’” http://slate.me/1Oxp6kw
OUT AND ABOUT: Dems and journos gathered at Tony Podesta’s Kalorama house for David Brock’s “Killing The Messenger: The Right-Wing Plot to Derail Hillary and Hijack Your Government”; shrimp and deviled eggs were among the hors-d’oeuvres.
SPOTTED: Mary Pat Bonner, Sen. Al Franken, Glenn Thrush, Jennifer Granholm, Ann Lewis, Gabe Debedenetti, Annie Karni, Ken Thomas, Michael Scherer, Bradley Beychok, Brad Woodhouse, Jessica Mackler, Eddie Vale, Mark Paustenbach, Michael Tomasky, Alex Seitz Wald, Molly Ball, Matea Gold, Lisa Lerer, Julie Bykowicz, Mary Jennings, Clark Jennings, Laura Quinn, Caroline Ciccone.
 --RealClearPolitics celebrated its 15th anniversary last night at the Longview Gallery in Shaw. Guests were treated to a #tbt-inspired playlist, with a DJ playing hits from 2000, the year of the polling and news aggregation site’s founding.
 SPOTTED: Tom Bevan and Carl Cannon, Erin Waters, David Corn, Tammy Haddad, Kelley McCormick, Gerry Petrella, Amy Rush, Kenny Day, Polson Kanneth, Brad Dayspring, Jim Manley, Reid Wilson, Ron Fournier, Chris Thorne, Jill Zuckman, Cori Kimball, Alex Isenstadt, Zeke Miller, Patrick and Anne Gavin, Erin McPike, Francesca Chambers, Brendan Kownacki, Dan Swartz, Caitlyn Huey-Burns, Nikki Schwab, Sam Feist, Lauren Vicary, Margaret Carlson, Lynn Sweet, Esther Baruh, Glenn Thrush, Pam Stevens, Rich Galen, Gene Sperling.
SPORTS BLINK: “SportsCenter” anchor Zubin Mehenti last night: “You gotta wonder if Matt Williams is in his final 10 days as [Nats] manager. [Regular season ends Oct. 4, at Mets.] I don’t think it’s unfair to ask, at all.”
BIRTHWEEK (was yesterday): Derek Pangallo of the Senate Office of Public Records and a new Partners alum ... Stan Kahn … former Minn. Gov. Arne Carlson (was Wednesday): American Forest Foundation CEO Tom Martin ... Francis Creighton, EVP of gov’t affairs at Financial Services Roundtable
BIRTHDAYS: Avis Cotton, a loyal “Morning Joe” viewer (son tip: Senator Tom) … Josh Tyrangiel of Bloomberg Media ... April Greener, research director for Leader Pelosi ... Barbara Walters is 86 ... former Defense Secretary Robert Gates is 72 ... Rep. Gregory Meeks is 62 ... Jack Howard, SVP of congressional and public affairs at the Chamber (h/t Blair Holmes) ... Politico’s Bob King is 5-0 -- celebrated last night with current and former colleagues, his brother, cake, pumpkin ale, cards, an AARP newsletter and geriatric magazines (h/ts Nirvi Shah, Joanne Kenen, Marty Kady, and Carol Eisenberg) ... Jake Suski, a Snyder and Huntsman alum (h/t Tim Miller) … Tim Reynolds (h/ts Hadley, JSD) … AP’s Evan Berland ... WSJ’s Danny Yadron … Liz Margolis ... HuffPost’s Ryan Reilly ...
... TNR’s Brian Beutler … Missy Owens, JRB’s niece and former Clinton White House press aide ... Harrison Taylor Godfrey, manager of state gov’t affairs at Invenergy and an Obama alum, who was engaged to Natalie Draisin on July 3, four years to the day outside the house where they first met – pic of the proposal: http://bit.ly/1KCXhAl ... Nicco Mele, author, co-founder of Echo & Co., former deputy publisher at the LA Times and currently senior fellow at USC Annenberg Center on Communication Leadership & Policy (h/t Jon Haber) ... Gary Carpentier ... DOE’s Pat Hart, a FEMA and Chris Dodd alum (h/t Jen Wlach) ... Emily Keech, executive director for the Republican Secretaries of State Committee and Cantor alum (h/t Tyler Threadgill) ... Jack Zahora ... Lauren Loftus ... Sophie Reagan ... Shivonne Foster, a strategic comms. senior associate at GPG ... Christine Harbin Hanson, deputy director of federal affairs at Americans for Prosperity ...
... Lila Shapiro of HuffPo … Ed Newberry, global managing partner at Squire Patton Boggs ... Pocketts, the Boston terrier of Romney alum Will Ritter, now of Poolhouse … Will Bergstrom … John Elias … National Journal’s Vivyan Tran, a Politico alum … Garlin Gilchrist II, the City of Detroit’s first ever deputy technology director for Civic Community Engagement and a MoveOn alum ... Dena Kozanas, deputy chief of staff for Rep. Candice Miller … NY Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie ... Playbook stalwart Robert Walden -- who played Donald Segretti in “All the President’s Men” and Lou Grant’s favorite reporter, Joe Rossi – is 72 … Tim Connolly ...
... Philip Dufour ... Shawn Burke ... Jeannie Doherty ... Rob Ritchie (h/ts Teresa Vilmain) ... Nathaniel Ennis ... Kelly Parks Snider, co-founder at Project Girl ... Amber Pfau ... Mimi Hall, director of public education and outreach at Nuclear Threat Initiative ... Jose Guardia ... Dave Peluso ... Chau Lan Ngo ... Michael Douglas is 71 ... Cheryl Tiegs is 68 ... Mimi Kennedy is 67 ... Heather Locklear is 54 ... Basketball Hall of Famer Scottie Pippen is 50 ... Will Smith is 47 ... Catherine Zeta-Jones is 46 ... Zach Woods ("Silicon Valley,” “The Office”) is 31 ... actress Emmy Clarke is 24 (h/ts AP)
** A message from the American Bankers Association: High-profile data breaches underscore the need for stronger and more innovative security solutions that protect consumers. Banks and payment networks continue to invest heavily in the development and implementation of promising new technologies that protect consumers everywhere purchases are made. Some people want Congress to mandate a static payments technology. That would be a mistake, as security safeguards would be quickly out of date. Mandates hinder the ability to adapt and react to evolving threats. Let’s Innovate. Not Mandate. Learn more at letsinnovatenotmandate.com **

                                            By 
                                                    Michael D'Antonio


                                            By 
                                                    Philip Gordon


                                            By 
                                                    Indira A.R. Lakshmanan

description: WHY RUBIO FINALLY THUMPED TRUMP -- BROOKLYN: Emails retrieved by FBI ‘unlikely to be released’
title: POLITICO Playbook, presented by the American Bankers Association – POPE TO CONGRESS: ‘We must move forward together ... in a renewed spirit of fraternity’ -- WHY RUBIO FINALLY THUMPED TRUMP -- BROOKLYN: Emails retrieved by FBI ‘unlikely to be released’
